intro: Carpodetus fuscus, commonly known as the black alder, is a deciduous shrub or small tree native to western North America. It is characterized by its dark, fissured bark and opposite, elliptical leaves that turn red in the fall. The plant produces small, clustered flowers followed by cone-like fruits that contain winged seeds. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in riparian zones and mountainous regions. Carpodetus fuscus plays an important role in supporting local wildlife and stabilizing stream banks.
